name: generate
shortDescription: Generates and/or modifies files based on a schematic.

options.name: defaults
options.description: Disable interactive input prompts for options with a default.

options.name: dry-run
options.description: Run through and reports activity without writing out results.

options.name: force
options.description: Force overwriting of existing files.

options.name: help
options.description: Shows a help message for this command in the console.

options.name: interactive
options.description: Enable interactive input prompts.

options.name: schematic
options.description: The [collection:schematic] to run.

subcommands.name: app-shell
subcommands.shortDescription: Configures your project to generate an app-shell during build time.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the app-shell should be generated.

subcommands.name: application
subcommands.shortDescription: Generates a new Angular application within your workspace. This schematic sets up the foundational structure of your project, including the root component, module, and configuration files. You can customize various aspects of the application, such as routing, styling, and testing.

options.name: inline-style
options.description: Include the styles for the root component directly within the `app.component.ts` file. Only CSS styles can be included inline. By default, a separate stylesheet file (e.g., `app.component.css`) is created.

options.name: inline-template
options.description: Include the HTML template for the root component directly within the `app.component.ts` file. By default, a separate template file (e.g., `app.component.html`) is created.

options.name: minimal
options.description: Generate a minimal project without any testing frameworks. This is intended for learning purposes and simple experimentation, not for production applications.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new application. This name will be used for the project directory and various identifiers throughout the application's code.

options.name: prefix
options.description: A prefix to be added to the selectors of components generated within this application. For example, if the prefix is `my-app` and you generate a component named `my-component`, the selector will be `my-app-my-component`.

options.name: project-root
options.description: The directory where the new application's files will be created, relative to the workspace root. If not specified, the application will be created in a subfolder within the `projects` directory, using the application's name.

options.name: routing
options.description: Generate an application with routing already configured. This sets up the necessary files and modules for managing navigation between different views in your application.

options.name: skip-install
options.description: Skip the automatic installation of packages. You will need to manually install the dependencies later.

options.name: skip-package-json
options.description: Do not add dependencies to the `package.json` file.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test files `spec.ts`.

options.name: ssr
options.description: Configure the application for Server-Side Rendering (SSR) and Static Site Generation (SSG/Prerendering).

options.name: standalone
options.description: Create an application that utilizes the standalone API, eliminating the need for NgModules. This can simplify the structure of your application.

options.name: strict
options.description: Enable stricter bundle budget settings for the application. This helps to keep your application's bundle size small and improve performance. For more information, see https://angular.dev/tools/cli/template-typecheck#strict-mode

options.name: style
options.description: The type of stylesheet files to be created for components in the application.

options.name: view-encapsulation
options.description: Sets the view encapsulation mode for the application's components. This determines how component styles are scoped and applied.

options.name: zoneless
options.description: Generate an application that does not use `zone.js`.

subcommands.name: class
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new class in your project. Classes are the fundamental building blocks for object-oriented programming in TypeScript. They provide a blueprint for creating objects with properties and methods. This schematic helps you generate a new class with the basic structure and optional test files.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new class. This will be used to create the class file (e.g., `my-class.ts`) and, if enabled, the corresponding test file `my-class.spec.ts`.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the class should be added. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the new class.

options.name: type
options.description: Adds a custom type to the filename, allowing you to create more descriptive class names. For example, if you set the type to `helper`, the filename will be `my-class.helper.ts`.

subcommands.name: component
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new Angular component. Components are the basic building blocks of Angular applications. Each component consists of a TypeScript class, an HTML template, and an optional CSS stylesheet. Use this schematic to generate a new component in your project.

options.name: change-detection
options.description: Configures the change detection strategy for the component.

options.name: display-block
options.description: Adds `:host { display: block; }` to the component's stylesheet, ensuring the component renders as a block-level element. This is useful for layout purposes.

options.name: export
options.description: Automatically export the component from the specified NgModule, making it accessible to other modules in the application.

options.name: export-default
options.description: Use a default export for the component in its TypeScript file instead of a named export.

options.name: flat
options.description: Create the component files directly in the project's `src/app` directory instead of creating a new folder for them.

options.name: inline-style
options.description: Include the component's styles directly in the `component.ts` file. By default, a separate stylesheet file (e.g., `my-component.css`) is created.

options.name: inline-template
options.description: Include the component's HTML template directly in the `component.ts` file. By default, a separate template file (e.g., `my-component.html`) is created.

options.name: module
options.description: Specify the NgModule where the component should be declared. If not provided, the CLI will attempt to find the closest NgModule in the component's path.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new component. This will be used to create the component's class, template, and stylesheet files. For example, if you provide `my-component`, the files will be named `my-component.ts`, `my-component.html`, and `my-component.css`.

options.name: ng-html
options.description: Generate component template files with an '.ng.html' file extension instead of '.html'.

options.name: prefix
options.description: A prefix to be added to the component's selector. For example, if the prefix is `app` and the component name is `my-component`, the selector will be `app-my-component`.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the component should be added. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: selector
options.description: The HTML selector to use for this component. If not provided, a selector will be generated based on the component name (e.g., `app-my-component`).

options.name: skip-import
options.description: Do not automatically import the new component into its closest NgModule.

options.name: skip-selector
options.description: Skip the generation of an HTML selector for the component.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of unit test files `spec.ts`.

options.name: standalone
options.description: Generate a standalone component. Standalone components are self-contained and don't need to be declared in an NgModule. They can be used independently or imported directly into other standalone components.

options.name: style
options.description: Specify the type of stylesheet to be created for the component, or `none` to skip creating a stylesheet.

options.name: type
options.description: Append a custom type to the component's filename. For example, if you set the type to `container`, the file will be named `my-component.container.ts`.

options.name: view-encapsulation
options.description: Sets the view encapsulation mode for the component. This determines how the component's styles are scoped and applied.

subcommands.name: config
subcommands.shortDescription: Generates configuration files for your project. These files control various aspects of your project's build process, testing, and browser compatibility. This schematic helps you create or update essential configuration files with ease.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the configuration file should be created or updated.

options.name: type
options.description: Specifies the type of configuration file to generate.

subcommands.name: directive
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new directive in your project. Directives are used to extend the behavior or appearance of HTML elements and components. They allow you to manipulate the DOM, add custom attributes, and respond to events. This schematic generates the necessary files and boilerplate code for a new directive.

options.name: export
options.description: Automatically export the directive from the specified NgModule, making it accessible to other modules in the application.

options.name: flat
options.description: Creates the new directive files at the top level of the current project. If set to false, a new folder with the directive's name will be created to contain the files.

options.name: module
options.description: Specify the NgModule where the directive should be declared. If not provided, the CLI will attempt to find the closest NgModule in the directive's path.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new directive. This will be used to create the directive's class and spec files (e.g., `my-directive.directive.ts` and `my-directive.directive.spec.ts`).

options.name: prefix
options.description: A prefix to be added to the directive's selector. For example, if the prefix is `app` and the directive name is `highlight`, the selector will be `appHighlight`.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the directive should be added. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: selector
options.description: The HTML selector to use for this directive. If not provided, a selector will be generated based on the directive's name (e.g., `appHighlight`).

options.name: skip-import
options.description: Do not automatically import the new directive into its closest NgModule.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the new directive.

options.name: standalone
options.description: Generate a standalone directive. Standalone directives are self-contained and don't need to be declared in an NgModule. They can be used independently or imported directly into other standalone components or directives.

options.name: type
options.description: Append a custom type to the directive's filename. For example, if you set the type to `directive`, the file will be named `example.directive.ts`.

subcommands.name: enum
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new enum in your project. Enums (enumerations) are a way to define a set of named constants, making your code more readable and maintainable. This schematic generates a new enum with the specified name and type.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new enum. This will be used to create the enum file (e.g., `my-enum.enum.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the enum should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: type
options.description: Adds a custom type to the filename, allowing you to create more descriptive enum names. For example, if you set the type to `status`, the filename will be `my-enum.status.ts`.

subcommands.name: environments
subcommands.shortDescription: Generates and configures environment files for your project. Environment files allow you to define different settings and configurations for various environments, such as development, testing, and production. This schematic helps you create and manage these files, making it easier to customize your application's behavior for each environment.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the environment files should be created or updated.

subcommands.name: guard
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new route guard in your project. Route guards are used to control access to parts of your application by checking certain conditions before a route is activated. This schematic generates a new guard with the specified name, type, and options.

options.name: flat
options.description: Creates the new guard files at the top level of the current project. If set to false, a new folder with the guard's name will be created to contain the files.

options.name: functional
options.description: Generate the guard as a function instead of a class. Functional guards can be simpler for basic scenarios.

options.name: implements
options.description: Specifies the type(s) of guard to create. You can choose one or more of the following: `CanActivate` (controls access to a route), `CanActivateChild` (controls access to child routes), `CanDeactivate` (asks for confirmation before leaving a route), `CanMatch` (determines if a route can be matched).

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new route guard. This will be used to create the guard's class and spec files (e.g., `my-guard.guard.ts` and `my-guard.guard.spec.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the guard should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the new guard.

options.name: type-separator
options.description: The separator character to use before the type within the generated file's name. For example, if you set the option to `.`, the file will be named `example.guard.ts`.

subcommands.name: interceptor
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new interceptor in your project. Interceptors are used to intercept and modify HTTP requests and responses before they reach their destination. This allows you to perform tasks like adding authentication headers, handling errors, or logging requests. This schematic generates the necessary files and boilerplate code for a new interceptor.

options.name: flat
options.description: Creates the new interceptor files at the top level of the current project. If set to false, a new folder with the interceptor's name will be created to contain the files.

options.name: functional
options.description: Creates the interceptor as a function `HttpInterceptorFn` instead of a class. Functional interceptors can be simpler for basic scenarios.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new interceptor. This will be used to create the interceptor's class and spec files (e.g., `my-interceptor.interceptor.ts` and `my-interceptor.interceptor.spec.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the interceptor should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the new interceptor.

options.name: type-separator
options.description: The separator character to use before the type within the generated file's name. For example, if you set the option to `.`, the file will be named `example.interceptor.ts`.

subcommands.name: interface
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new interface in your project. Interfaces define the structure of objects in TypeScript, ensuring type safety and code clarity. This schematic generates a new interface with the specified name and type.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new interface. This will be used to create the interface file (e.g., `my-interface.interface.ts`).

options.name: prefix
options.description: A prefix to be added to the interface name. This is typically not used for interfaces, as they don't have selectors like components or directives.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the interface should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: type
options.description: Adds a custom type to the filename, allowing you to create more descriptive interface names. For example, if you set the type to `data`, the filename will be `my-interface.data.ts`.

subcommands.name: library
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new library project in your Angular workspace. Libraries are reusable collections of components, services, and other Angular artifacts that can be shared across multiple applications. This schematic simplifies the process of generating a new library with the necessary files and configurations.

options.name: entry-file
options.description: The path to the library's public API file, relative to the workspace root. This file defines what parts of the library are accessible to applications that import it.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new library. This name will be used for the project directory and various identifiers within the library's code.

options.name: prefix
options.description: A prefix to be added to the selectors of components generated within this library. For example, if the prefix is `my-lib` and you generate a component named `my-component`, the selector will be `my-lib-my-component`.

options.name: project-root
options.description: The root directory for the new library, relative to the workspace root. If not specified, the library will be created in a subfolder within the `projects` directory, using the library's name.

options.name: skip-install
options.description: Skip the automatic installation of packages. You will need to manually install the dependencies later.

options.name: skip-package-json
options.description: Do not automatically add dependencies to the `package.json` file.

options.name: skip-ts-config
options.description: Do not update the workspace `tsconfig.json` file to add a path mapping for the new library. The path mapping is needed to use the library in an application, but can be disabled here to simplify development.

options.name: standalone
options.description: Create a library that utilizes the standalone API, eliminating the need for NgModules. This can simplify the structure of your library and its usage in applications.

subcommands.name: module
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new, generic NgModule definition in the given project.

options.name: flat
options.description: Create the new files at the top level of the current project root.

options.name: module
options.description: The declaring NgModule.

options.name: name
options.description: The name of the NgModule.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project.

options.name: route
options.description: The route path for a lazy-loaded module. When supplied, creates a component in the new module, and adds the route to that component in the `Routes` array declared in the module provided in the `--module` option.

options.name: routing
options.description: Create a routing module.

options.name: routing-scope
options.description: The scope for the new routing module.

options.name: type-separator
options.description: The separator character to use before the type within the generated file's name. For example, if you set the option to `.`, the file will be named `example.module.ts`.

subcommands.name: pipe
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new pipe in your project. Pipes are used to transform data for display in templates. They take input values and apply a specific transformation, such as formatting dates, currency, or filtering arrays. This schematic generates the necessary files and boilerplate code for a new pipe.

options.name: export
options.description: Automatically export the pipe from the specified NgModule, making it accessible to other modules in the application.

options.name: flat
options.description: Creates the new pipe files at the top level of the current project. If set to false, a new folder with the pipe's name will be created to contain the files.

options.name: module
options.description: Specify the NgModule where the pipe should be declared. If not provided, the CLI will attempt to find the closest NgModule in the pipe's path.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new pipe. This will be used to create the pipe's class and spec files (e.g., `my-pipe.pipe.ts` and `my-pipe.pipe.spec.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the pipe should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: skip-import
options.description: Do not automatically import the new pipe into its closest NgModule.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Prevent the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the new pipe.

options.name: standalone
options.description: Generate a standalone pipe. Standalone pipes are self-contained and don't need to be declared in an NgModule. They can be used independently or imported directly into other standalone components, directives, or pipes.

options.name: type-separator
options.description: The separator character to use before the type within the generated file's name. For example, if you set the option to `.`, the file will be named `example.pipe.ts`.

subcommands.name: resolver
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new resolver in your project. Resolvers are used to pre-fetch data before a route is activated, ensuring that the necessary data is available before the component is displayed. This can improve the user experience by preventing delays and loading states. This schematic generates a new resolver with the specified name and options.

options.name: flat
options.description: Creates the new resolver files at the top level of the current project. If set to false, a new folder with the resolver's name will be created to contain the files.

options.name: functional
options.description: Creates the resolver as a function `ResolveFn` instead of a class. Functional resolvers can be simpler for basic scenarios.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new resolver. This will be used to create the resolver's class and spec files (e.g., `my-resolver.resolver.ts` and `my-resolver.resolver.spec.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the resolver should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the new resolver.

options.name: type-separator
options.description: The separator character to use before the type within the generated file's name. For example, if you set the option to `.`, the file will be named `example.resolver.ts`.

subcommands.name: service
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new service in your project. Services are used to encapsulate reusable logic, such as data access, API calls, or utility functions. This schematic simplifies the process of generating a new service with the necessary files and boilerplate code.

options.name: flat
options.description: Creates files at the top level of the project or the given path. If set to false, a new folder with the service's name will be created to contain the files.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new service. This will be used to create the service's class and spec files (e.g., `my-service.service.ts` and `my-service.service.spec.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the service should be added. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: skip-tests
options.description: Skip the generation of a unit test file `spec.ts` for the service.

options.name: type
options.description: Append a custom type to the service's filename. For example, if you set the type to `service`, the file will be named `my-service.service.ts`.

subcommands.name: service-worker
subcommands.shortDescription: Adds a service worker to your project. Service workers enable your application to work offline or on low-quality networks by caching assets and intercepting network requests. This schematic configures your project to use a service worker.

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project to add the service worker to. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: target
options.description: The build target to apply the service worker to. This is typically `build`, indicating that the service worker should be generated during the standard build process.

subcommands.name: web-worker
subcommands.shortDescription: Creates a new web worker in your project. Web workers allow you to run JavaScript code in the background, improving the performance and responsiveness of your application by offloading computationally intensive tasks. This schematic generates the necessary files for a new web worker and provides an optional code snippet to demonstrate its usage.

options.name: name
options.description: The name for the new web worker. This will be used to create the worker file (e.g., `my-worker.worker.ts`).

options.name: project
options.description: The name of the project where the web worker should be created. If not specified, the CLI will determine the project from the current directory.

options.name: snippet
options.description: Generate a code snippet that demonstrates how to create and use the new web worker.
